RICHMOND EASILY
DOWNED IN TRACK
Hopkins Romps to Easy Win
Over Virginian Runners
ISSUE

NEVER

IN

.PRICE 5 CENTS

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 8, 1928

VOL. XXXII, No. 53

DOUBT

Jays Win All But Three Events
in Annual Dual Meet
Beginning with the first event,
in which the Hopkins trio of sprinters thundered in to take first, second and third in the century dash,
the Blue Jay trackmen upset the
predictions of dopesters and literally ran away with the dual meet with
Richmond College on Saturday at
Homewood field. When the dust of
the combat rolled away it was
found that the Black and Blue had
piled up the most decisive lead this
year, and were victors by a wide
margin, the final score being 85 to
41. At no time during the afternoon were the Southerners within
striking distance of a win. A long
bus ride from Richmond in the hot
weather probably had much to do
with the unexpected poor showing
of the Virginians in the various
running events.

SCABBARD AND BLADE
ELECTS FIVE MEMBERS
Men pledged this year to
Scabbard and Blade, honorary
military society, are William
Banks, Fibel, C. H. Wyatt,
Eldridge Wolfer, and M. H.
Medenbach. The initiation of
these men will take place on
either the 14th or 21st of May.
This is the first year that
non-commissioned officers are
being pledged and initiated.
This is being done with the
permission of national headquarters of the R. 0. T. C.
Heretofore, it had been the
custom to commission the men
as second lieutenants and then
grant advancement after initiation.

Committee Decides
On Rushing Season

HOPKINS TO DEBATE
UNIV. OF N. CAROLINA
De Tocqueville Medal Contest
To Be Held May 10.
Thursday night Wilmer H. Driver and John B. Littlefield will
journey down to Chapel Hill to debate with the University of North
Carolina team the question, "Resolved, That the United States
Should Cease to Protect by Armed
Force American Private Capital
Invested Abroad, Except After a
Formal Declaration of -War." Driver and Littlefield will debate the
affirmative side of the question.
While the two Hopkins men are
arguing in North Carolina, two men
from Chapel Hill will come to
Homewood to debate the affirmative side of the resolution with two
Jay men.
Is the Second Trip This Year
This will be the second trip of
the season for the debating team,
the first being to New York, where
the Hopkins team lost to the team
representing N. Y. U. in a debate
on the subject that will be debated
at Chapel Hill on Friday.
On Monday the question, "Resolved, That the Eighteenth Amendment Should be Repealed," will be
the "bone of contention" between
the Black and Blue debaters and the
debaters from Northwestern University. "This debate, which will
take place in the C. E. Building,
ought to have a good audience owing to the fact that the subject in
question is so interesting to the
student body," said H. Garland
Hershey, president of the Debating
Council.

SCHOULER LECTURE
ON THIS THURSDAY
-The Problem of Orient
and Occident" is the title of
the next of the James Schouler lectures to be given this
,Thursday by Dr. Edgar J.
Fisher. Dr. Fisher is vitally
interested in this subject, for
he is Dean and Professor of
History at Robert College,
Constantinople.
The lecture will be held in
the Civil Engineering Building
at 5 P. M. The public is invited to attend.

EDITORIAL COMMENT

Honorary Fraternities:—There is something innately meet and
right about groups like 4). B. K. and its red-haired step-child O. D. K.
They were conceived in a happy moment by gentlemen keenly conscious
of the fact that man must have his crown of wild olive. The only weakness of such organizations lies in the impossibility of always selecting
just the right men, and of always keeping out ,the wrong ones, but I
imagine (D. B. K. largely overcomes this difficulty by putting the qualifications on a purely objective, statistical basis. 0. D. K. is unfortunately
subject to every flaw of human nature, for it attempts to choose human
beings. In any case, taken together, these two fraternities are the most
justidable organizations of undergraduates.

Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
The agent while going through his
plunder stored in our baggage room
came across a can of your tobacco, and
account of his not using a pipe he made
me a present of this tobacco.
You will note the revenue stamp
and your memo which was inclosed.
The tobacco was put up in 1910, sixteen years ago. But it was in good
shape, of remarkable flavor, and was
greatly enjoyed by me.
Thought you would be interested in
knowing how your tobacco held out in
these days of fast living.
Yours very truly,
(signed) Gordon McDonald

"That such a cleavage existed is
a singular example of the foresight of our forefathers," said the
Honorable Charles -Warren, referring to the prolonged controversy
over Mississippi trade rights, in the
third of a series of lectures on "Anti-Federalism and the Constitution,"
delivered last Thursday. Mr. Warren devoted this lecture to the subject, "How Navigation of the Mississippi Affected the Constitution."
During the summer of 1778
George Rogers Clarke seized the last
remaining British settlements on
the Mississippi and claimed this immense western territory for the
Federation.
There was grave fear felt, however, during the ten subsequent
years for the development of commerce along the Mississippi. Spain
held the territory at the mouth of
the river, and viewed with disapproval all efforts made towards securing free passage by American
colonists through her possessions,
while the South and North were
violently opposed to any concessions to Spain in the way of jeopardizing trade rights.
France Opposed

(Continued on page 4, column 1)

CONTROL

Fear of Robert Morris Affected
Executive Power

The French Ambassador to this
country in 1778 sought to prevent
and discourage American settlement in this new region.
The West as then known consisted only of that region south of the
Ohio river. That large stretch of
land to the north played no part in
the controversy, which had been
purely theoretical up to the year
1782, when the first _ American
trader made the journey from Pittsburgh south along the Ohio to New
Orleans.
The Western settlers now realized the importance of securing control of the river mouth and, consequently, any move that would interfere with this control they opposed
at the Constitutional Convention in
1787. It was mainly regarding
treaty powers that the South and
North fought the Federalists and
finally secured the provision that
two-thirds of the Senate -present
must concur with any treaty drawn
up by the executive power. The
Middle States regarded this new
West with a jealous alarm and were
earnestly endeavoring to put every
possible restriction on these future
States. "It seems hardly possible,"
said Mr. Warren, discussing this
view, "that such leading men could
take such a short-sighted view of
the situation."

Friday's Lecture

On Friday, Mr. Warren continued the series with a lecture On
"How Robert Morris Inspired Fear
of Executive Power." Robert Morris, as first Superintendent of the
Treasury, conducted his office with
such an autocratic and domineering
manner that he inspired a lasting
fear of executive power in the
framers of the Constitution. "It
was the acts and conduct of one
man who prevented further powers
from being granted to Congress or
the President," Mr. Warren said,
referring to Morris. The anti-Federalists sought to put many restrictions on the President because of
this fear, but only partially secured
their aims.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 8, 1928

VOL. XXXII, No. 53

DOUBT

Jays Win All But Three Events
in Annual Dual Meet
Beginning with the first event,
in which the Hopkins trio of sprinters thundered in to take first, second and third in the century dash,
the Blue Jay trackmen upset the
predictions of dopesters and literally ran away with the dual meet with
Richmond College on Saturday at
Homewood field. When the dust of
the combat rolled away it was
found that the Black and Blue had
piled up the most decisive lead this
year, and were victors by a wide
margin, the final score being 85 to
41. At no time during the afternoon were the Southerners within
striking distance of a win. A long
bus ride from Richmond in the hot
weather probably had much to do
with the unexpected poor showing
of the Virginians in the various
running events.

SCABBARD AND BLADE
ELECTS FIVE MEMBERS
Men pledged this year to
Scabbard and Blade, honorary
military society, are William
Banks, Fibel, C. H. Wyatt,
Eldridge Wolfer, and M. H.
Medenbach. The initiation of
these men will take place on
either the 14th or 21st of May.
This is the first year that
non-commissioned officers are
being pledged and initiated.
This is being done with the
permission of national headquarters of the R. 0. T. C.
Heretofore, it had been the
custom to commission the men
as second lieutenants and then
grant advancement after initiation.

HOPKINS TO DEBATE
UNIV. OF N. CAROLINA
De Tocqueville Medal Contest
To Be Held May 10.
Thursday night Wilmer H. Driver and John B. Littlefield will
journey down to Chapel Hill to debate with the University of North
Carolina team the question, "Resolved, That the United States
Should Cease to Protect by Armed
Force American Private Capital
Invested Abroad, Except After a
Formal Declaration of -War." Driver and Littlefield will debate the
affirmative side of the question.
While the two Hopkins men are
arguing in North Carolina, two men
from Chapel Hill will come to
Homewood to debate the affirmative side of the resolution with two
Jay men.
Is the Second Trip This Year
This will be the second trip of
the season for the debating team,
the first being to New York, where
the Hopkins team lost to the team
representing N. Y. U. in a debate
on the subject that will be debated
at Chapel Hill on Friday.
On Monday the question, "Resolved, That the Eighteenth Amendment Should be Repealed," will be
the "bone of contention" between
the Black and Blue debaters and the
debaters from Northwestern University. "This debate, which will
take place in the C. E. Building,
ought to have a good audience owing to the fact that the subject in
question is so interesting to the
student body," said H. Garland
Hershey, president of the Debating
Council.

SCHOULER LECTURE
ON THIS THURSDAY
-The Problem of Orient
and Occident" is the title of
the next of the James Schouler lectures to be given this
,Thursday by Dr. Edgar J.
Fisher. Dr. Fisher is vitally
interested in this subject, for
he is Dean and Professor of
History at Robert College,
Constantinople.
The lecture will be held in
the Civil Engineering Building
at 5 P. M. The public is invited to attend.

EDITORIAL COMMENT

Honorary Fraternities:—There is something innately meet and
right about groups like 4). B. K. and its red-haired step-child O. D. K.
They were conceived in a happy moment by gentlemen keenly conscious
of the fact that man must have his crown of wild olive. The only weakness of such organizations lies in the impossibility of always selecting
just the right men, and of always keeping out ,the wrong ones, but I
imagine (D. B. K. largely overcomes this difficulty by putting the qualifications on a purely objective, statistical basis. 0. D. K. is unfortunately
subject to every flaw of human nature, for it attempts to choose human
beings. In any case, taken together, these two fraternities are the most
justidable organizations of undergraduates.

Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
The agent while going through his
plunder stored in our baggage room
came across a can of your tobacco, and
account of his not using a pipe he made
me a present of this tobacco.
You will note the revenue stamp
and your memo which was inclosed.
The tobacco was put up in 1910, sixteen years ago. But it was in good
shape, of remarkable flavor, and was
greatly enjoyed by me.
Thought you would be interested in
knowing how your tobacco held out in
these days of fast living.
Yours very truly,
(signed) Gordon McDonald

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 8, 1.928

WISDOM OF FATHERS
Attitude of Middle States Held
as "Short-sighted"

New Members of Board of Managers
Nominated by Cabinet

"That such a cleavage existed is
a singular example of the foresight of our forefathers," said the
Honorable Charles -Warren, referring to the prolonged controversy
over Mississippi trade rights, in the
third of a series of lectures on "Anti-Federalism and the Constitution,"
delivered last Thursday. Mr. Warren devoted this lecture to the subject, "How Navigation of the Mississippi Affected the Constitution."
During the summer of 1778
George Rogers Clarke seized the last
remaining British settlements on
the Mississippi and claimed this immense western territory for the
Federation.
There was grave fear felt, however, during the ten subsequent
years for the development of commerce along the Mississippi. Spain
held the territory at the mouth of
the river, and viewed with disapproval all efforts made towards securing free passage by American
colonists through her possessions,
while the South and North were
violently opposed to any concessions to Spain in the way of jeopardizing trade rights.
France Opposed

(Continued on page 4, column 1)

CONTROL

Fear of Robert Morris Affected
Executive Power

The French Ambassador to this
country in 1778 sought to prevent
and discourage American settlement in this new region.
The West as then known consisted only of that region south of the
Ohio river. That large stretch of
land to the north played no part in
the controversy, which had been
purely theoretical up to the year
1782, when the first _ American
trader made the journey from Pittsburgh south along the Ohio to New
Orleans.
The Western settlers now realized the importance of securing control of the river mouth and, consequently, any move that would interfere with this control they opposed
at the Constitutional Convention in
1787. It was mainly regarding
treaty powers that the South and
North fought the Federalists and
finally secured the provision that
two-thirds of the Senate -present
must concur with any treaty drawn
up by the executive power. The
Middle States regarded this new
West with a jealous alarm and were
earnestly endeavoring to put every
possible restriction on these future
States. "It seems hardly possible,"
said Mr. Warren, discussing this
view, "that such leading men could
take such a short-sighted view of
the situation."

Friday's Lecture

On Friday, Mr. Warren continued the series with a lecture On
"How Robert Morris Inspired Fear
of Executive Power." Robert Morris, as first Superintendent of the
Treasury, conducted his office with
such an autocratic and domineering
manner that he inspired a lasting
fear of executive power in the
framers of the Constitution. "It
was the acts and conduct of one
man who prevented further powers
from being granted to Congress or
the President," Mr. Warren said,
referring to Morris. The anti-Federalists sought to put many restrictions on the President because of
this fear, but only partially secured
their aims.

At Playshop Today

All candidates for the Black and
Blue Jay Orchestra are requested to

Clayton Hamilton, for twenty
years one of the foremost authorities on American drama, will lecture at the Playshop tonight on
"Sardou and Diplomacy." In the
afternoon Mr. Hamilton will speak
to Dr. John E. Uhler's American
drama class. Both lectures are
open to students, especially that at
the Playshop, which will be followed by a dance.
Mr. Hamilton, who is touring the
country in connection with George
Tyler's golden jubilee revival of
Sardou's great drama,"Diplomacy,"
visited Baltimore four years ago
with the sesquicentennial revival of
"The School for Scandal." For
many years he has lectured on
drama at Columbia. He has, in
throughout
traveled
addition,
Europe and visited many places in
Africa and Asia. His books are
numerous, dealing mostly with
drama and with figures from Aeschylus to ONeill.
